title: Hurricane Maria was a partly manmade disaster.
description: This project visualizes the death toll caused by a hurrican.
design method: wash painting style, negative illustration or photographs

title: Lost Mothers
description: This work talks about the mothers who died in childbirth in the US and reported the stories of 16 mothers.

title: John Hopkins COVID-19 Map
description: A dashboard of Covid-19 statistics.

title: 2017: the safest skies record
description: This project visualizes the accidents in sky in 2017.

title: In Africa, a virus spreads
description: A project about the outbreak of Ebola in Africa.

title: Cost of Health Care by Country
description: The cost of health care by different countries and regions.

title: How Bad Is Unemployment? ‘Literally Off the Charts’
description: The visualization of the jobless rate in the US.

title: A Bird’s-Eye View of How Protesters Have Flooded Hong Kong Streets
description: The visualization of the protesters in Hong Kong.
design method: dense data point, negative illustration or photographs

title: How the coronavirus spread in Hong Kong
description: How Covid-19 has been spread in Hong Kong.

title: 可视化|新冠逝者：献给疫情中离去的生命
description: A visualization project that documents the dead people in the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: 11699位患者和我们的这一年
description: The Covid-19 epidemiologic investigation in China.
design method: dark color tone, visual metaphor - negative metaphor

title: The angry face of nature
description: A project that visualizes the notable natural disasters in the world.

title: China is surprisingly carbon-efficient—but still the world’s biggest emitter
description: The amount of the CO2 emission of China.

title: sepsin
description: This project visualizes the emotions expressed by Trump's twitters.
design method: dark color tone, visual metaphor - negative metaphor

title: CEO pay ratio
description: A comparison between the salary of CEOs and ordinary people.

title: On the Front Page, a Wall of Grief
description: A visualization that uses 500,000 dots to represent the individual people who died because of Covid-19, showing how fast the pandemic is crossing the US.
design method: dense data point, low-granuarity data & details

title: The Project Behind a Front Page Full of Names
description: A big list of the names of people who died in the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: The terrible numbers that grow with each mass shooting
description: A story that visualizes the gun shootings in the US and the gun death toll.

title: 百万逝者：新冠何以成为全球悲剧？
description: A visualization of the confired C0vid-19 cases and death in the world.

title: Out of Sight, Out of Mind
description: A stroy that visualizes the innocent Pakistan people who were attacked by drones.

title: Iraq's bloody toll
description: An infographic that depicts the dead soldiers who sacrificed during the Iraq war.

title: A view on despair
description: An infographic that visualizes the suicide in the Netherland in 2017.

title: 53027条留言背后，网络树洞里绝望者的自救与互助
description: A visual analysis of the texts left by a melancholiac who has committed suicide.

title: What does 425,000 Covid deaths sound like? I
description: Using sound to encode the death toll provided by NYT.

title: going gray
description: A project that visualizes the aged population in Japan.
design method: dark color tone, visual metaphor - negative metaphor, negative illustration or photographs

title: The Stories behind a line
description: A visual story of six asylum seekers' routes. They travelled from their hometown to Italy.

title: The Ocean Cleanup
description: A project that visualizes how plastic is sent to the ocean through various rivers in the world.
design method: dark color tone, guided cue, real-time counter, location / gsp

title: My Plastic Footprint
description: A data physicalization. The author recycled the plastic she used and made them into sea turtles.

title: Imaging Mental Health in America
description: The psychological health of American people.

title: Who has died from Covid-19 in the US?
description: Vox analyzed the mortality rate of Covid-19 in the past year by different genders, regions, and races.
design method: negative illustration or photographs, dark color tone, uncontrollable and unevitable animation

title: The true death toll of COVID-19
description: The eatimated global excess mortality in the world.

title: One Year, 500,000 Deaths
description: A story that tells how serious the Covid-19 pandemic is in the US.
design method: exaggerated sizing, uncontrollable and unevitable animation

title: What vets are experiencing
description: A story that reveals the current state of the ex-servicemen in the US.

title: The age of the “megafire”
description: This story visualizes the biggest 38 megafired in western US.

title: Beneath the blue: dive into a dazzling ocean under threat
description: A story about ocean pollution. The authors split the depth of the ocean into segments and explain the pollution in each segment.

title: Lifelines: a pandemic undertow
description: This story calls for the attention to the need of psychological caring after the outbreak of Covid-19.
design method: warning, negative illustration or photographs, uncontrollable and unevitable animation

title: How the Virus Won
description: A data story that explains where the Covid-19 virus origined and how it spread to the world.

title: A visual analysis of theMeToo Movement
description: This story collected the posts about the #Metoo topic and analyzed these materials using data visualization.

title: A plateful of plastic: Visualising the amount of microplastic we eat
description: This project uses data physicalization to show how much plastic we eat every day.
design method: data physicalization - negative material, abnormal coloring

title: Educate your child
description: A newsgame that asks users to make decisions for the education of their children and shows the consequences.
design method: first person view / immersive role play

title: People of the Pandemic
description: A newsgame that mimics how your outdoor activities will influence the spread of the virus in the community.
design method: first person view / immersive role play

title: Coronavirus: How can we imagine the scale of Covid's death toll?
description: A project that visualizes the spread and the death toll of Covid-19.
design method: visual metaphor - negative metaphor, wash painting style

title: THE DOOMSDAY DATA VISUALIZATIONS (Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists)
description: A story that talks about the crisis for human beings, including the nuclear war, climate change, and disruptive technology.

title: India Elections 2019: The figures behind the faces
description: The candidates in India elections. Women also account for a little part.
design method: negative illustration or photographs, dense data point, suspenseful layout

title: The Unlikely Odds of Making it Big
description: There are a lot of bands in New York but only a few of them have made a success.

title: We Wait
description: A newsgame. Users act as the Syrian refugees and experience how they leave their country and wait for a new life.
design method: first person view / immersive role play, hook task, music and sounds

title: Mapping Police Violence
description: A story that talks about the violence used by the police officers and how it affects the community.
design method: uncontrollable and unevitable animation, dense data point, supplemental file, exaggerated sizing, most dramatic perspective in the title/beginning

title: Explore 17,369 officers who used force in N.J.
description: A story that investigates how the policemen in NJ used force and why.
design method: dense data point, exaggerated sizing, location / gsp, low-granuarity data & details

title: Using the Interaction Geography Slicer to Visualize New York City Stop & Frisk
source: IEEE 2017 VISAP Paper, Ben Rydal Shapiro & Francis A. Pearman, II
description: The statistics of the Stop & Frisk in New York show that black people are more frequently stopped by cops.

title: A GROWING WHIRLPOOL
description: A project that visualized the endangered birds, their current status, and how to protect them.
design method: dense data point, uncontrollable and unevitable animation, low-granuarity data & details, visual metaphor - negative metaphor

title: U.S. Gun Deaths
description: 可视化了美国执法部门报告的枪支凶杀案数据，并利用世界卫生组织的美国死亡率数据估算这些受害者本来的潜在寿命与死亡原因。

title: The Fallen of World War II
link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DwKPFT-RioU 官网视频，在07:20, 16:20； 图表可交互：http://www.fallen.io/ww2/
description: 第二次世界大战的死亡人数，并将数字与历史上的其他战争相比较，包括最近冲突的趋势

title: The Water We Eat
description: 可视化人类平均每天的用水量，以及这些用水是哪些地方产生的

title: One LGBT+ person is killed every day in Brazil
Do you know who's wathcing you
How Belarusian police beat protesters
description: 展示了白俄罗斯执法部门如何有系统地、完全不受惩罚地殴打抗议者；利用人物插画剪影代表 1,406 名受伤人员来可视化这些伤害以及受伤位置。

title: Drowning in plastic
description: 可视化一小时、一天、一个月、一年和过去十年中全球塑料瓶的高度，并将之与世界知名景点的高度作对比

title: Do you know Africa?
description: 可视化非洲地图，并让用户点击每个国家的地理位置

title: HeartSaver
description: HeartSaver将纽约市可以治疗心脏病的医院可视化于地图上，并让用户将心脏病患者安置在最合适的医院。

title: Wealth shown to scale
description: 可视化1000美元、十亿美元和Jeff Bezos的财富量

title: Wie lange arbeiten Sie für das Gehalt der anderen?
So schnell verdienen die deutschen Nationalspieler dein Monatsgehalt
Wissen Sie noch, wo Deutschland geteilt war?
description: draw the Berlin wall

title: How powerful was the Beirut blast?
Derek Chauvin was found guilty – how typical is that of US police who kill?
